channel.title: If you had to make an HTTP parser
channel.description:
How would you go about it? Please no 'use XYX'.
Also is anyone familiar with what browsers use character encoding wise for the request line/headers. To add, should I even be concerned with HTTP 2.0 and does anyone have a ballpark explanation of how it works compared to 1.1?
Thanks.
I've seen native implementations but I doubted that a native interface coupled with java would really see performance benefit s. Also discuss that.

item.title: If you had to make an HTTP parser
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Pwnd:

Ah I see. I have seen it used in the official Java library source code. It had a few methods here and there, so I guess I’m more strict about it.

The benefits in my opinion, is that you can easier reuse parts of your code, as each method should preferably do one indivisible operation. What an indivisible operation means in the current context, is pretty much up to the person writing the code. It could theoretically be a set of instructions on the bytecode-level. But I’m not that strict. In my case it could for instance be that I separate the precondition assertions, like checking for valid arguments and throwing Exceptions, from updating some field. Then, if I need to notify Observers of a state change, that is also in a separate method.

Another benefit I have noticed is that a lot of smaller (and less complex) methods can be easier for the JIT-compiler to optimize. Method-inlining will usually not be performed on large and complex methods.

Read full topic
item.source: If you had to make an HTTP parser

item.title: If you had to make an HTTP parser
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Pwnd: That’s just a habit of mine. I try to separate the public API code from the private implementation code, such that it’s easier to get an idea of what the public API code does simply by reading the verbose names of the private implementation methods.

Read full topic

item.title: If you had to make an HTTP parser
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

k, anyway.

Here’s the (partially) finished parser:

http://pastie.org/private/fefjp65itlwmosb82x04ug

Disclaimers:

Have to verify HTTP header size, have to verify content length, have to implement chunked transfer encoding, yes Im aware the body isnt always encoded as US ASCII, just to assure I didn’t fudge up the callback.

Designed to have a low memory footprint, be as fast as possible. Multiline header values come in chunky (multiple callbacks), have yet to make it so that it ignores the LWS and just keeps it to a single WS character.

Test:

package com.nyphrex.rs2.http;

import com.google.common.base.Charsets;
import org.junit.Test;
import org.junit.runner.RunWith;
import org.junit.runners.JUnit4;

import java.util.Arrays;

/**
 * Created by sini on 8/26/14.
 */
@RunWith(JUnit4.class)
public final class HttpParserTest {

    @Test
    public void def() {
        HttpParser parser = new HttpParser();
        parser.register(new HttpHandler() {
            @Override
            public void parsedRequestMethod(String method) {
                System.out.println("Method: " + method);
            }

            @Override
            public void parsedUrl(String url) {
                System.out.println("URL: " + url);
            }

            @Override
            public void parsedVersion(int major, int minor) {
                System.out.println("Version: " + major + "." + minor);
            }

            @Override
            public void parsedHeaderField(String field) {
                System.out.println("Header field: " + field);
            }

            @Override
            public void parsedHeaderValue(String value) {
                System.out.println("Header value: " + value);
            }

            @Override
            public void parsedBody(byte[] bytes, int off, int len) {
                System.out.println("Body: Off-" + off + ", Len-" + len + ", Val-" + new String(bytes, off, len, Charsets.US_ASCII));
            }
        });
        System.out.println(parser.parse("GET /happy.html HTTP/1.1\r\nContent-Length: 4\r\n\n0123".getBytes(Charsets.US_ASCII)));
    }
}

Result:

Method: GET
URL: /happy.html
Version: 1.1
Header field: Content-Length
Header value: 4
Body: Off-46, Len-4, Val-0123
50

Read full topic
item.source: If you had to make an HTTP parser

item.title: If you had to make an HTTP parser
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

vortex: I’m using Windows XP on my other laptop. Simply because I didn’t find Windows Vista or Windows 7 that appealing. A few days ago I bought a new laptop, so I got Windows 8 now too. I really like it.

t4: I like code that fails as soon as possible. Sure, accessing a method of a parameter would fail, but in other cases you could easily miss that. So I’ve started with this habit to not only address that issue, but also to be more explicit about what’s happening.

sinisoul: A scanner is a lexer (a lexical analyzer). I’m not using an AST in that language, as you noticed, but that’s just how it turned out. I could easily do that. But one nice feature in my language, is that I can stream tokens with no end. That’s not really possible in an AST, as you create the AST before you start interpreting it. My language is one long sequence, like a list, rather than a graph (a tree). I can also decide how to interpret the tokens based on what interpreters I happen to use at the time. That could be done in a graph as well, but it’s probably easier in a list.

Read full topic

item.title: If you had to make an HTTP parser
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

I just now uploaded another one of my parsers / languages.

The scanner, which supports Regexes, can be found here: https://github.com/WavePropagation/org.cel4j.eleonore/blob/master/src/main/org/cel4j/eleonore/Scanner.java

A script that the language, called Eleonore, can run: https://github.com/WavePropagation/org.cel4j.eleonore/blob/master/resources/Eleonore_Script.els

Ashi: Yes, Java 8 is really awesome. The reason I just started with it, is because the installer does not support Windows XP by default. Then I recently “hacked” the installer, and successfully got it to work.

Read full topic

item.title: If you had to make an HTTP parser
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Tree, post:12, topic:548217”][quote author=Ashi link=topic=667123.msg4461345#msg4461345 date=1417683369]

Here’s one of my solutions to parsing. It’s been used for my top-down (recursive descent) parser, parsing Java 7 and partially Java 8.

https://github.com/WavePropagation/org.cel4j.node/blob/master/src/main/org/cel4j/node/Source.java

Edit: It also supports converting String literals formatted like Unicode escapes into their equivalent Unicode char values.

I don’t like that code.
[/quote]

Just leave Ashi.[/quote]
Not my fault it has premature loop exits, unhandled exceptions and some outdated code (which can be done in Java 8).
There’s also the doHasNextString(String), which creates a for loop for no reason.

It’s also only half documented

Read full topic
